column2: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies common variants associated with blood pressure variation in east Asians.
column4: Kato N and Takeuchi F and Tabara Y and Kelly TN and Go MJ and Sim X and Tay WT and Chen CH and Zhang Y and Yamamoto K and Katsuya T and Yokota M and Kim YJ and Ong RT and Nabika T and Gu D and Chang LC and Kokubo Y and Huang W and Ohnaka K and Yamori Y and Nakashima E and Jaquish CE and Lee JY and Seielstad M and Isono M and Hixson JE and Chen YT and Miki T and Zhou X and Sugiyama T and Jeon JP and Liu JJ and Takayanagi R and Kim SS and Aung T and Sung YJ and Zhang X and Wong TY and Han BG and Kobayashi S and Ogihara T and Zhu D and Iwai N and Wu JY and Teo YY and Tai ES and Cho YS and He J
column6: We conducted a meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies of systolic (SBP) and diastolic (DBP) blood pressure in 19,608 subjects of east Asian ancestry from the AGEN-BP consortium followed up with de novo genotyping (n = 10,518) and further replication (n = 20,247) in east Asian samples. We identified genome-wide significant (P < 5 x 10(-8)) associations with SBP or DBP, which included variants at four new loci (ST7L-CAPZA1, FIGN-GRB14, ENPEP and NPR3) and a newly discovered variant near TBX3. Among the five newly discovered variants, we obtained significant replication in the independent samples for all of these loci except NPR3. We also confirmed seven loci previously identified in populations of European descent. Moreover, at 12q24.13 near ALDH2, we observed strong association signals (P = 7.9 x 10(-31) and P = 1.3 x 10(-35) for SBP and DBP, respectively) with ethnic specificity. These findings provide new insights into blood pressure regulation and potential targets for intervention.
